description: Combat Application Tourniquet, produced by North American Rescue.  This windlass tourniquet officially in use with the U.S. Army is intended for stopping hemorrage in battlefield and pre-hospital conditions.  While not easy to use, it may save your life.  The strap is currently wide enough for use on an average adult's arm.  Activate to adjust size and location.

description: A roll of hypoallergenic cloth medical tape, produced by Cardinal Health under the Kendall brand.  Used to hold an absorbent pad or hemostatic wound dressing in place and under pressure.

description: A sterile 4″×4″ gauze pad, produced by Bound Tree Medical under the Curaplex brand.  Intended to be secured in place over a bleeding wound, using a length of medical tape or a bandage, to stem the bleeding.  Cannot be used on its own, since in doesn't adhere to the skin for medical reasons.
//weight: basic weight (density; 13.2 g/m3) × area of swab (4 in^2 = 16 in2) × ply (layers; 12)

notes: weight_per_m2 is converted to weight_per_cm2 (g/cm2) in order to calculate over density (g/cm3)

//use_action: with nothing to hold the pad in place, it can't be used reliably as wound dressing
good-quality pads avoid sticking to the skin in order to not disturb the wound when the first-aid bandage is pulled away

description: A coarse powder of yellow-ish granules, produced by Celox.  When used on a wound, significantly stems any bleeding by sealing the wound under a gel-like substance.  The hemostatic properties of the granules come from the contained chitosan: a polysaccharide produced from crustacean chitin.  However, the application of the granules have not caused a single allergic reaction in almost 20 years that the hemostatic has been used.
//volume: we derive the volume of the 15 grams of granules from the volume difference between a full and an empty sachet (see item used as `container`)
//charges: instructions call to apply the entire 15-gram package's worth of hemostatic granules to the wound

description: A brown stretchy bandage with a large gauze pad sewn to it, 4 inches wide.  Intended to control severe bleeding, it can soak up a large amount of liquid, as well as apply constant pressure to the wound, thus aiding clotting rate.  Lightweight and flat-packed to optimize volume inside an emergency response kit, it's meant to be a part of a swift-response kit, such as those carried by EMS and tactical medics.

use_action.//move_cost: quicker to apply due to simply construction and Velcro locking mechanism

description: A thin white gauze rolled up, 3 inches wide.  Intended to be wrapped around a shallow wound, or packed into a deep wound, in order to promote clotting and stem bleeding.  Impregnated with kaolin, this wound dressing accelerates natural clotting, making controlling even severe bleeding much easier.
//longest_side: assumes the dressing is folded into a roll when in the inventory
